posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
This will be the Chief Delphi thread for Choreo 2025 releases and support.

The post marked as “Solution” in this thread points to the latest release.

Choreo (Constraint-Honoring Omnidirectional Route Editor and Optimizer, pronounced /koʊˈɹiːoʊ/, like K + “Oreo”) is a graphical tool for planning time-optimized trajectories for the FRC autonomous mode. Each trajectory takes full advantage of the drivetrain’s performance, while obeying its dynamics constraints, such as top speed and maximum acceleration on each module. Choreo provides a variety of additional constraints that affect the generated trajectory, such as waypoints, keep-in and keep-out zones, limits on speed and acceleration, etc. Choreo provides a vendor library to load and follow the trajectories, but they are also compatible with PathPlannerLib.

Thank you to all the teams that used Choreo in 2024 and shared your needs, struggles, and suggestions for improvement. Our work for 2025 has focused on many issues and enhancements.

We have moved our documentation site to a new domain, https://choreo.autos .

This feature addresses a few struggles in 2024 Choreo:

Default units (SI, radians) being inflexible, unintuitive, and forcing the user to convert by hand.

No good way to define field constants or waypoint locations that are shared among all trajectories.

No good way to define robot configuration in terms of other constants (i.e. bumper size and module placement in terms of frame size.

To fix these, we have replaced almost every number input in the application with mathematical expression inputs, powered by (mathJS)[ https://mathjs.org/ ].

MathJS has full dimension awareness, so you can use whichever unit you like, and it will reject inputs that are not dimensionally correct.

Choreo allows you to define a project-wide set of variables that can be substituted into any appropriate expression in the project. Variables can be defined as single numbers with a variety of dimensions, but Choreo also has aggregate variables to organize the x, y, and heading components of an important pose.

The expression and variable features open up a wide range of capabilities, similar to parametric sketches in a CAD program. We’re excited to see how teams use these new tools.

Choreo 2024 asked for a wheelbase, track width, bumper length, and bumper width. This described many robots, but especially in 2024, many robots had intakes that made the bumpers not centered at the center of rotation, or they had module placement that was not centered or even rectangular. Choreo 2025 makes robot configuration more flexible, permitting and honoring these configurations.

NOTE: due to an expectation that 2025 would be a mirrored field like 2023 and 2025, Choreo 2025 currently only supports module and bumper dimensions that are symmetric across the robot x-axis (the front-back line, meaning left-right mirror symmetry). In robot configuration, users only edit the left side of the robot dimensions. Expect this to change, since asymmetric robots work with rotationally symmetric fields.

The motor calculator presets for determining motor max speed and motor max torque have been removed. Our formula for these has proved to be too aggressive, so the calculator was not helpful for torque values.

This issue was inherent to the architecture of Choreo, but through the architecture changes related to command-line generation, we were able to make generation individually cancelable at any point.

Previously, if Choreo did not calculate enough samples for a segment of the trajectory, the only option was a constant sample count override for each segment equally. Now, the target time delta can be set for each path, allowing Choreo to still take the length of the segment into account. Also, each waypoint besides the last one has its own sample count override (see details in the Waypoints section).

For swerve drive, Choreo 2025 modifies the internal logic of the solver to handle robot rotation as a unit vector instead of an angle number. This allows Choreo to take the fastest rotational movement, even if it would previously wrap -pi to pi and take the long way around. Therefore, heading initial guesses are not as important to manually tweak.

Choreo has added support for differential drive trajectories in ChoreoLib and throughout the application, but some elements of the generator are still in progress. The current version works well enough for many simple trajectories, especially in this game, but we’re not comfortable calling the feature as stable as swerve.

Choreo now ships with a command-line tool that takes in a .chor file and one or more associated .traj, and generates the .traj files, modifying them in-place. Further details will be described in the docs.

Choreo 2025 removes the ability to set the heading initial guess on translation and empty waypoints. Due to the above improvements to the solver, and other logic implemented to automatically calculate heading initial guesses, the feature was unnecessary, counterproductive, and cluttered the UI.

Choreo 2025 removes the (non-constrainable) initial guess point waypoint type and subsumes its functionality into the Empty Waypoint, whose location can be constrained using Keep-In or Keep-Out Zones. The Empty Waypoint can be the endpoint of a path, but not the start point.

Instead of a default sample override being applied to an entire path, with the same number of samples for each waypoint, Choreo 2025 has a checkbox on each waypoint to specify an individual override between that waypoint and the next.

The user interface for adding and editing constraints has been revised. Previously, a click target for adding a constraint was at every waypoint and the midpoint of every segment. Now, click one waypoint, then click the other, without the UI clutter.

When a constraint is selected, the field highlights the range it applies to. For constraints with additional field points/lines to modify (currently Point At, Keep In/Out Zones, and Keep In Lanes), the field will also display draggable field objects tied to the constraint.

The display also shows when hovering over the constraint in the sidebar.

Choreo 2025 adds a new type of constraint, which is a zone (currently rectangle or circle) that the robot must stay entirely inside, including the bumpers, for the duration of the constraint scope. A Keep-In Rectangle the size of the field will be part of new paths, but disabled by default for performance reasons.

A new constraint, Keep In Lane is an adjustable-width lane that constrains the center of the robot to be between the two parallel edges. This replaces the Straight Line constraint, and can be understood as a Straight Line constraint with a tolerance.

Obstacles have been changed to be part of the constraints system and renamed to Keep-Out Circles for consistency. While the solver still struggles in some obstacle setups, the ability to apply the constraint to only a section of the path makes the problem more feasible.

Choreo 2025 adds a checkbox to each constraint that allows the constraint to be disabled without being deleted. This can be useful for comparing the effects of individual constraints.

Choreo 2025 expands the additional checks on the trajectory, performed before starting the solver, which are intended to identify conflicting constraints and other causes of infeasibility. New checks include:

Verifying that Pose waypoints are not used with Point-At constraints

Verifying that 0 Max Angular Velocity constraints do not conflict with Pose waypoints with differing headings

More to come!

Splitting paths was previously done through a project-wide switch that made every Stop Point constraint be a path splitting point. In 2025, the Stop Point constraint is entirely separate from splitting. Every waypoint except for path endpoints has a checkbox which can be used to mark a waypoint as a split point. NOTE: Choreo does not enforce stopping at split points, but for most usage, adding a Stop Point constraint is still advised.

The releases now have many more artifacts than last year.

We support Windows, MacOS, and Linux on both x86_64 and arm64/aarch64 .

Users should normally be downloading:

Windows: the -setup installers for Windows,

MacOS: the .dmg,

Debian and Ubuntu: the .deb,

Fedora: the .rpm

Other Linux: the AppImage

Each of the above except for the AppImage installs the Choreo GUI and a separate executable for command-line generation. We hope to find a way to put the command-line functionality into the main Choreo app.

Finally, we have standalone executables. These are for others to set up unofficial repackaging (i.e. AUR packages for Arch Linux). Using the standalone executables directly is not recommended.

ChoreoLib has been added to the vendor dependency manager in WPILib VS Code. This is the recommended way to install ChoreoLib. See our docs for instructions on getting started.

ChoreoLib 2025 adds a new kind of auto sequencing library. It lets you build autonomous routines as a set of Triggers running commands instead of as one monolithic command group. With a control flow more similar to binding commands to driver controllers, your default commands and subsystem behavior works just like in teleop. For more on this API, see the AutoFactory docs .

NOTE: Choreo 2025 has no backwards compatibility to upgrade Choreo 2024 projects, but 2025 beta projects can be upgraded to the 2025 stable version without issue.

Choreo 2025 solves a few issues related to the design choices of .chor and .traj files in 2024.

The prior design, where all “source” data is in one monolithic .chor file, caused issues with auditing changes and merge conflicts in version control.

Furthermore, the practice of exporting split trajectories as individual .traj files was fragile and depended on file system operations to find all the sections.

Finally, the design that put the .chor file in project root and the .traj files in the deploy directory required logic to determine the relative path between the project root and deploy directory. This logic was difficult to maintain and interfered with testing outside a robot project.

With the addition of event markers, .traj files had to be updated at times other than successful generations.

The .chor had to save the last generation and a portion of the data used to generate it, for rendering purposes. This duplicated significant information.

Without a full snapshot of the last generation’s input, the logic to determine if the trajectory needed to be regenerated was hacky and based on the undo history.

To address the above issues, Choreo 2025 uses the following schema:

.chor:

Holds the robot config and the project-wide variables, as well as other project-wide settings.

Now is placed adjacent to the .traj files. Both .chor and .traj should be in the deploy/choreo directory for robot code integration.

Both .chor and .traj should be in the deploy/choreo directory for robot code integration.

.traj:

Describes one continuous trajectory per Choreo “path”. Due to the splitting feature, a single .traj file also contains sample indices which robot libraries can use to split the trajectory.

Is both an input and output file for the app. Deleting the .traj deletes the path completely.

Except for project-wide information in the .chor, it contains all necessary information for Choreo to present, edit, and generate the trajectory, and for the robot code to load and follow it.

NOTE:

For debugging purposes, we will now need the full directory including both .chor and all .traj. We have a function in Choreo (“Export Diagnostic Report” in the main menu) to produce a .zip of the project files and program logs, which will be requested when asking for support.

In general, use the same Choreo GUI and ChoreoLib versions.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Get It Here!

(v2025.0.1 is the first full release, but had enough bugs that we delayed the announcement thread to v2025.0.2)

This release brings critical fixes to ChoreoLib in all three languages and usability improvements in the UI. We also now build the UI and CLI for Linux aarch64.

Disable or delete the default field border Keep In Rect constraint on any paths that do not need it. Especially on simpler paths, it has been shown to significantly affect generation time. In this update, the constraint is disabled by default.

BREAKING: .chor files need to be saved in [project root]/deploy/choreo now. Docs here have been updated to match.

Fixed a bug with load_trajectory() requiring absolute paths. After doing the above file move, use the trajectory name alone, such as choreo.load_trajectory("testPath") to load [project root]/deploy/choreo/testPath.traj .

Fixed several compilation errors, so the C++ library is usable now.

Fixed behavior of AutoFactory.trajectoryCmd(...) . It is now a command that requires the drivetrain, so can be used in sequence with resetOdometry as intended.

Fixed an issue with the AutoTrajectory.done() Trigger where it would sometimes not switch true at the end of the trajectory, especially when running the trajectory a second time.

Fixed a bug where a zero-max-angular-velocity constraint between a pose and translation waypoint would fail in a way that required manual correction beyond undoing that setup.

Fixed an issue with two identical waypoints in sequence, which would cause an error about “nonfinite cost or constraints”. Both waypoints now constrain the same sample in the path. This situation is not recommended, but is intended to at least generate if the constraints are compatible.

Fixed an issue with variables that depend on other variables. This would cause a UI crash if the dependency variable was deleted. Now it shows the depending variable as an invalid input.

Variables in the variable panel are now visually sorted alphabetically, but still separated between standalone variables and pose variables.

Fixed an issue with the icons in the path list, where trajectories would be incorrectly shown as out-of-date upon opening a project.

Added a Generate All Outdated button above of the path list, next to the Add Path and Duplicate Path buttons.

The Keep In Rect constraint for the field borders is disabled in new paths. For paths that do not get near the wall, the constraint is an unnecessary performance hit.

No breaking changes. However, the .chor variables section is now always saved in alphabetical order by variable name. Previously it was nondeterministic and changed almost every time a variable was modified. This change should reduce lines changed in source control diffs.

link_counts.title: Release Choreo v2025.0.2 · SleipnirGroup/Choreo · GitHub
Saving - Choreo Documentation
Choreo 2025 Beta

posts.cooked:
Amicus1:

No breaking changes. However, the .chor variables section is now always saved in alphabetical order by variable name. Previously it was nondeterministic and changed almost every time a variable was modified. This change should reduce lines changed in source control diffs.

Another benefit is you see what actually changed. I was looking at diffs of .chor files a few days ago and I couldn’t figure out what actually changed because most of the diff was variables shifting around.

I do have one question: Will Choreo (ideally using PathPlannerLib but if only using ChoreoLib works that’s also acceptable) work if I have multiple .chor files in my robot project? I’m attempting to make the code work for two different robots, which of course have different physical constants, so they need different project files. If there is a way to also generate the same paths for both projects, that would be great, but I can do that by hand, as long as it is at least possible to have this setup.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Unfortunately we don’t really support this. There’s a way you might be able to do it but I don’t want to say anything without trying it myself.

posts.name: Anish M
posts.cooked:
Thank you for the new updates with 2025.0.2! Taking out the “Keep In Rectangle” constraint cut down the trajectory generation time by a lot.

Also a quick question: Do you have any examples on how to use the different types of event markers in Choreo? We’ve been doing good with “Named” markers so far, but we don’t know how to correctly use the other types (Wait, Sequence, Parallel, etc.) in Java.

Any help would be much appreciated.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The command group types are for PathPlanner compatibility only and don’t matter for ChoreoLib (the markers get loaded, but ChoreoLib always looks at the marker name instead of the command configuration attached, so it’s useless data.) If the command group layout is not working in PathPlannerLib, then it’s something to get mjansen involved in.

posts.name: Jackson
posts.cooked: Did they remove the Choreo autos in pathplanner, and are choreo and pathplanner still compatible?  Pathplanner used to have two Autos that you could make: a pathplanner auto or a choreo auto. When I tried to make a new auto, it only allowed me to make a Pathplanner Auto. Am I going insane or is it gone for good?

posts.name: Anish M
posts.cooked: Do you guys know how to properly use & do the Robot Configuration in Choreo?
You need to generate a path in Choreo, and then the Choreo Autos option should appear again.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Did you already check the documentation?

A graphical tool for planning time-optimized trajectories for autonomous mobile robots in the FIRST Robotics Competition.

link_counts.title: Robot Configuration - Choreo Documentation

posts.name: Jackson
posts.cooked: I already generated a path using Choreo and the option still doesn’t show up, is there any reason why this might happen?
Did you place your .chor under deploy/choreo?

posts.name: Anish M
posts.cooked: Yes. I mean specifically how to find the Wheel COF and MOI.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
For CoF, this chart by Spectrum is pretty good.

Spectrum 3847 | Build Blog 2024 FRC Open Alliance

For MoI, our docs have a page on how to calculate MoI from sysid tests, or if your CAD is accurate with materials, you can measure it from there. MoI modeling is an approximation anyway, especially as large superstructure elements (arms, etc) move across the robot. If MoI is too large, paths with significant rotation will be slower than they could be. If it is too small, the robot won’t be able to keep up, so it’s better to overestimate.

link_counts.title: Spectrum 3847 | Build Blog 2024

posts.name: Jackson
posts.cooked: When I add a stop to the path, it doesn’t give me an option for that section of the path.  The only paths I have access to are path and path.0 despite adding multiple stops.  Does anyone know the solution?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The stop points do not automatically split the path in 2025. There is a separate checkbox on the waypoint config panel for split points. The goal of this was to improve flexibility for placing stop points and split points.

posts.name: Jackson
posts.cooked: I have the checkboxes on the constraints tab on the left side checked.  Is that the config panel you are referring to?  If so what else could be wrong?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The split checkbox is per-waypoint and is on the panel where you specify waypoint x, y, and heading.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Get It Here!

This release brings a few features related to variables, some new ChoreoLib AutoTrajectory Triggers, other ChoreoLib bugfixes, and internal changes.

The waypoint configuration panel now has a searchable input to assign a pose variable to the waypoint. If you type a name that does not exist, it has an option to use the current waypoint expressions for a new pose variable.

The input does not show the last assigned variable, due to there being no waypoint-wide “assignment” property.

The search is “fuzzy” so it will include all the variables that include the search text. This means that for reef pose variables such as L1, R1, L2, R2...R6 , typing 1 or L or R might be useful shortcuts.

The expression fields in the pose variable list are now labeled matching the way they are accessed.

Updated trajectory schema version to be correct

Fixed several major type safety bugs.

Switched to dataclasses for SwerveSample, SwerveTrajectory, DifferentialSample, DifferentialTrajectory, and EventMarker

Added mypy type checking to our CI setup to catch further issues.

Changed isAutonomousEnabled checks to isEnabled , allowing Choreo usage in teleop. This does mean AutoRoutines do not automatically end on a transition from auto directly to teleop (a nearly sim-only situation). However, if using RobotModeTriggers.autonomous().whileTrue() or the default template getAutonomousCommand() , those have mechanisms to end the routine when autonomous ends.

This does mean AutoRoutines do not automatically end on a transition from auto directly to teleop (a nearly sim-only situation).

However, if using RobotModeTriggers.autonomous().whileTrue() or the default template getAutonomousCommand() , those have mechanisms to end the routine when autonomous ends.

Added AutoRoutine.idle() , returning a Trigger that goes false at the start and true at the end of every routine.trajectory.cmd() command. idle() can be true when the routine is not being polled.

Deprecated AutoRoutine.anyDone(...) in favor if AutoRoutine.anyDoneDelayed(...) with identical usage.

Added AutoRoutine.allInactive(AutoTrajectory, AutoTrajectory...) , returning a Trigger that is true when none of the provided trajectories are running, but the routine is still being polled.

AutoTrajectory : New Triggers, which standardize on seconds instead of cycles for delays. Deprecated done(int cycles) . Added doneDelayed(double seconds) which rises to true a given time after the trajectory ends and falls on the next robot cycle. Added doneFor(double seconds) which rises to true when the trajectory ends and falls after a given time. Added recentlyDone() which rises to true when the trajectory ends and falls when another begins. Added atTimeBeforeEnd(double timeBeforeEnd) which is similar to atTime but offsets from the end of the trajectory.

Deprecated done(int cycles) .

Added doneDelayed(double seconds) which rises to true a given time after the trajectory ends and falls on the next robot cycle.

Added doneFor(double seconds) which rises to true when the trajectory ends and falls after a given time.

Added recentlyDone() which rises to true when the trajectory ends and falls when another begins.

Added atTimeBeforeEnd(double timeBeforeEnd) which is similar to atTime but offsets from the end of the trajectory.

AutoTrajectory : Other new features Added chain(AutoTrajectory other) which is shorthand for .done().onTrue(other.cmd()) Added spawnCmd() which schedules the .cmd() and ends instantly. This is useful for ending a command group, such as:

Added chain(AutoTrajectory other) which is shorthand for .done().onTrue(other.cmd())

Added spawnCmd() which schedules the .cmd() and ends instantly. This is useful for ending a command group, such as:

This is useful for ending a command group, such as:

Without the secondTrajectory being scheduled separately from the sequence , it will be part of the sequence , which has all the requirements of score() , specifically the intake. This would lead to the sequence being cancelled when secondTrajectory triggers another intake command.
